If you looked at half of the globe and put all of the land on it... only half of what you saw would be land.

The entire rest of the world would be water.

I messed up the end of that because I was worried about the character limit. Let me correct it...
 Our days are not 24.0025 hours each, they are 24.06ms each, by those calculations, with each "hour", instead of their previously being made up of (2.7778e-10)*3600 microseconds (whereas there are 3600 seconds in an hour), are now made up of (2.7778e-10)+(.06/24) microseconds.

Not necessarily ;)

Let us assume that this is true -- our day is now .06 microseconds (which I will incorrectly abbreviate to "ms") longer. Is that .06ms more sunlight? .06ms more nighttime? Or is it .06ms evenly distributed (.03 day and .03 night)?

Any of these means our days are no longer 24hrs.

 The only case in which your school time would be extended is if the 0.06ms was spread out over every hour of the day, .06ms/24=0.0025, meaning our days would be separated into 24.0025 hours each ^^

That is why substances that form ions when solved are soluble in water in the first place: for example, normal salt (NaCl) forms the ions Na+ and Cl-. Those ions "attach" themselves to the partially charged water molecule to the proper parts (negative charge attracting positive and vice versa). However, other substances like lipids/waxes that have few or no partially charged atom bondings (the electronegative difference between H and C is close to 0), that's why those don't develop H bonds.

Water molecules have a so called partial charge: since the oxygen within the atom attracts the shared electron more than the hydrogen atoms (higher electronegativity), the oxygen atom is slightly negatively charged, while the hydrogen is slightly positively charged. This partial charge leads to diverse electrochemical behaviour, such as the so called hydrogen bonds. They're not like your standard covalent bonds, but still have a pretty important role especially in organic chemistry.

Each Hydrogen ion in a water molecule has a side that's completely positive and a side that's completely negative, as the electron orbiting each hydrogen atom is stuck orbiting it in the vicinity of the oxygen atom, because that's what an INTRAMOLECULAR bond is, electron sharing. If you get an atom with a negative side (such as Cl- in NaCl), it will be attracted to the hydrogen atom in the water molecule. THAT is called an INTERMOLECULAR bond.

The O has a much higher electronegativity than H, which means that its nucleus will have a much stronger attraction to the shared electrons of the O-H bonds. The H side of the bond will be much more positive and attract negative particles.
This happens with every non-symmetrical bond, but the effect is particularly strong with O-H bonds, to the point where the H nucleus (=proton) is said to be kind of "shared" between the O (to which it is covalently bonded), and the other negative particle.

@SuperNeonCupcakes :A tid bit about Joseph Meister. After he was attacked by a rabid dog the vaccination for him  was done at some personal risk for Pasteur, since he was not a licensed physician and could have faced prosecution for treating the boy. After consulting with colleagues, Pasteur decided to go ahead with the treatment. Meister did not contract the disease. So in conclusion,Pasteur took a leap of faith and gave the boy the vaccination which ended in a good way :)

@SuperNeonCupcakes : You can't heal rabies.. Once the rabies virus enters your brain then no matter what ever treatment we give the patient dies. The vaccines just boost up our immune responses such that the virus is killed before it enters into the brain. So we can prevent rabies but unfortunately we can't heal :(.. Believe me here in india every year 20,000 people die with rabies thanks to the prevalence of rabies virus among the stray dogs. (I am a doctor so know the stuff and statistics)

Just to clarify, like michael said, hydrophobia in humans is not fear of swimming or oceans or bodies of water. that is aquaphobia which is tied in with a fear of drowning. hydrophobia is fear of getting wet at all. there is a link however, because like in the video, the man with rabies was reacting reflexively to the liquid, and his body was acting not only hydrophobic, but aquaphobic, because his body did not want to drown. so fascinating. thanks for everything you guys do at vsauce!

The dams might not be something to worry about, but it makes me wonder about the "butterfly effect". Slightly slowing Earth's rotation would also effect our gravity, and would have to have some effect on the planet. Everything from the plates shifting to weather would be changed, if even by a small fraction. Although we might not notice it now, wouldn't those effects increase over time? Our environment is more fragile than people think, and we can never tell what might cause a negative reaction.

@KillerKamster That effect is awesome! It's called the Leidenfrost effect and it happens when a liquid hits a surface MUCH hotter than its boiling point. It's also why Mythbusters was able to dip their wet fingers in molten lead for a couple seconds :)
